Comment: A fact known by few is this. The federal government controls most of Alaska's land followed by the State of Alaska. The third largest land holders are Alaska Native regional, village and individual parcels established thought the Alaska Native Land Claims Settlement Act decades ago. This means Alaska Natives are the largest private land holders in Alaska.
How these various individual and private entities have handled their land is as varied as the people who own and manage them. Two different Native corporations are represented in my neighborhood. One subdivided their land and sold it. Another deeded their land over to the National Park Service asking only to be allowed to practice traditional subsistence activities on them in exchange.
One size does not fit all so expect lots of different land options to be explored in the future. You might like some and maybe not others but it is up to Alaska Natives to decide just like anyone gets to decide the fate of the land they own in America.

Comment: I'm thinking that it's you who should be embarrassed for implying that the same overpopulation that occurs in some parts of the world is equally present here in Canada.

Case in point, Afghanistan has about the same population as Canada.
Afghanistan also happens to be about the same size as Saskatchewan.
Yet Saskatchewan has 1 million people vs. Afghanistan at 34 million
And I'm guessing that Saskatchewan also has a heck of a lot more arable land than Afghanistan.

I'm not suggesting for a second that we should stuff 34 million into Saskatchewan, but if you're trying to suggest that Canada is anywhere close to being overpopulated, then you seriously need to give your head a shake!

Comment: Recent Catholic Voting History:

--President George W. Bush won the Catholic vote, 52 percent to 47 percent, in his 2004 re-election effort, according to exit polls from that cycle. President Barack Obama won the group (which made up 27 percent of the electorate, according to exit polling), 54 percent to 45 percent, during his bid for the White House in 2008.

But to call the Catholic vote a pure bellwether would be a mistake; the determination of an individual’s vote is more likely in 2012 to turn on more common political variables (like income, education, or ethnicity) – than simple religious identity. nBC

--Catholics - the country's largest religious group with one-quarter of the population - have supported the winner of the popular vote in every election since 1972. Comment: In the U.S. all spending and tax bills MUST come from Congress.  The President can suggest budgets, they can veto some bills (though doing so tends to use up a lot of political capital), but they can't pass budgets.

So to understand deficits in the U.S. you really need to look at who was in Congress, not the White House.

The surpluses that the U.S. enjoyed in the late 1990's came during the period that the Republicans controlled Congress.  The massive deficits from fiscal 2007 through 2011 occurred when the Democrats controlled Congress.  The shrinking deficits more recently were during a split Congress (Republicans holding the House of Representatives and the Democrats holding the Senate).

Comment: You say, "With respect...if there is anything that the American experience has taught us it is that a big, muscular, independent public broadcaster, not in any way dependent upon commercial sources of revenue, is essential to the survival of a healthy democracy."

"With respect", America hasn't taught us anything of the sort.  I assume, OldBanister, you're talking about PBS and National Public Radio.  12% of PBS funding is derived directly from the federal government.  18% of National Public Radio is derived directly and indirectly from the federal government. 

Much of the funding for both is derived from private (business) corporations. On-air credit, as you likely know, is a form of "attaboy" advertising and pr.  So much for "not in any way dependent upon commercial sources of revenue..." 

Quite recently, a NPR spokesperson said (in a bid, I suspect, maintain the revenue stream flowing) that if the the federal government stopped its support, the organization would suffer seriously.

Comment: The role of "church" in our culture? 
Our Church accepts the premise, expressed by Aristotle, long before and without Jesus, that "a mutual benevolence mutually known" is the basis of civility. Think about it: willing (doing, not just talk) the good, the absence of harm for one another is the basis of sustainable community.  
The option is one (or few) dominating the other(s). It assumes that  "other(s)" are tools, resources, disposable, to be used and/or that "other(s) are incompetent, incapable of reciprocal "benevolence". 
I can't speak for other faiths, but, our Christ tradition teaches three principle cultural premises:
1. the Aristotle notion of civility (2+2=4) is assumed and expanded to go beyond to assist those incapable of "benevolence", those for whom survival is paramount, assisting them, risking to fullness of inclusion (2+2=5)
2. that both are now of divine value
3. Teach 1&2, and ensure that the option of domination, the proclivity to "use" is exposed & resisted.
Novel

Both mainstream parties have become the "war" parties, they both seem to think that foreign adventures are important, but sadly, I think that has to do with how big our military budget has become.  As the military gets larger, there is a push to use it.  I do think we need a strong defense, but we have a roughly 3000 mile moat around 2 sides of our country, so that is a pretty big defense all on its own, many seem to forget that.

Comment: Ultimately, the problem with Toronto's sports franchises is that they are owned in whole or in part by the nation's dominant media networks who are entirely unmotivated to deliver a dominant competitive product. Rogers and Bell control the stadiums, radio access, television access and online access to their sporting products. They don't need these teams to win in order to rake in a profit. They only need for people to care. 

Fans think that by not buying tickets to games, they're sending a message. Well, as long as you're still paying to stream the games online and you still have Sportsnet and Raptors TV on cable, you're still supporting the team, and you're probably spending more than you would if you bought a ticket.

The only way to TRULY get the attention of Rogers or Bell is to completely cut yourself off from the entire genre of sports entertainment, and I think that's a bridge too far for most true fans... and Rogers knows it.  It's been fun, Jays!

Comment: Getting out of debt ... the best suggestion is to try to get a job with the police force, whether as a police officer or in some kind of a support role.  The pay will be substantially better than the roughly $12/h she is making now, and it will help her get out of debt.  Once that's done, she can reassess and either try to get a more suitable job on the police force, somewhere else, or even go back to school.  But 2-4 years on the police force won't be so terrible and it'll help resolve her debt dilemma.
If she really doesn't want to do that, then consider taking on a second, part-time, job to supplement the earnings.  Even just working Saturdays for $10/h could double her loan repayment capability.
Moving back home, giving away the cat, I think these are unreasonable sacrifices given how frugally she is already living.

Comment: I have been down on Story for most of the year. So many empty at bats, so many times where he would swing his heart out at a pitch he can't hope to hit, and then on the next pitch he'd stand with the bat on his shoulder as a belt-high fastball whizzed past him for strike three. But, all year long his defense has been very good bordering on outstanding (he didn't look like an all-star defender to me much last year, but this year he's been just about as good as anybody out there defensively), and although the strikeouts are still there he does seem to be making much better contact, and more often, over the last month or so. 

That last month has convinced me that he could be a big component of the Rockies going forward, where in June and July I wasn't so sure their best option might not be to look elsewhere. Good turnaround Trevor, keep it up!

Comment: Pete Buist, the eastern boundary of Denali National Park and Preserve was not fixed by biological realities -- it was fixed by land ownership.  When ANILCA passed in 1980, the eastern boundary of Denali could not be moved further east by federal legislation, because the land to the east was (and is) owned by the State of Alaska.  

The easterly boundary of DNP was not establish with any recognition of the winter migratory range of Denali's wolves, following the caribou and other food sources.  That's why there needs to be a buffer that encompasses these state lands.  A simple solution that the BoG once implemented, but now refuses to consider despite strong public support for it.

i was involved wit the enactment of ANILCA and have been a member of the Board of Game, so I think I have a pretty good perspective on this issue.

Comment: That provides no evidence that the increase occurred after implementation of SB91.  The increase in robberies at one type of location could also be concurrent with a decrease in robberies at other types, suggesting a displacement of method by offenders rather than an increase in offending.  There are dozens of other questions like this one could ask and answer with existing data.

I'm not saying the effect of SB91 must be zero.  I'm saying we do not know because the analysis has not been done.  

We *could* put real data and analysis on this, but we have not, and it turns out this sort of policy analysis is more complex than isolating one type of robbery and comparing year-over-year change.

Comment: Ronin, I understand your point.  I teach reading comp to honors students, and always remind them to not let their biases lead them to see things that aren't there.  I see it's possible to interpret "...what was happening with REGARD to the Civil War..." to mean things happening in Jackson's time which eventually built up to the Civil War, especially if said by someone who's not precise about his choice of words.  Trump may be a "concept" person who means what he said about Jackson being angry at the dumb goings-on, and wasn't focusing on the exact years things happened.

But I hope you also recognize that most people who care about both informing and being understood would say something like, "Jackson was angry with the unreasonable things going on IN HIS TIME that eventually led to the Civil War."  If you don't say it the "common" way, you leave yourself open to the grammar police, political opponents, and those who really believe you're uneducated.

Comment: Regarding this point:  "The central bank has warned that a sharp rise in unemployment could set off a series of unfortunate events, including a house-price correction that would be particularly severe in ... Toronto and Vancouver. "

Oh dear.  The BoC really doesn't get it.  Take Vancouver.  Of course a rise in unemployment would be bad but the idea that it would result in a severe price correction in Vancouver doesn't hold up.  Take some guy making $62,000 a year.  Terrible if he loses his job but he isn't the one who is buying the $2,000,000 former drug den - already striped and ready for demolition! -  in East Van.  It's offshore money.  Prices are completely detached from local ability to pay.  How is this not obvious?

If anything the causation runs the other way.  Some exogenous shock reduces the demand for RE or reduces prices and THIS has the effect of reducing employment through reduction in RE and related areas.

Memo to JT-Read the SCMP/Ian Young for solutions and then act.

Comment: Family member drives Mazda 3, aside from rust it is a trouble-free car and feels very zippy in everyday driving. However, this feeling is not backed up by actual performance - I had that Mazda 3 on a track and it falls apart at above 80km/h - doesn't corner or stop well, brake fade is very pronounced, and understeer is very pronounced. So zippiness is all smoke and mirrors - shift points and first gear ratio to make you feel sporty.

Of all econoboxes that I drove on the track, I think 6th gen Civic hatch with MT is better handling car. I never seen anyone bring Elantra to the track, so I have no idea how it handles in such conditions. VW Golf and Passat handles surprisingly well, runner up to Civic.

This is not because of the physical aspects-his son shows every sign of being the size of Dad at six foot four and 225-but because of the culture of arrogance and bad behavior that seems to be indulged with star athletes at all levels. As a high school teacher I've seen those kids who had the path made smooth for them. Sooner or later they crash and burn. That is what we're seeing played out on a national scale with Kaepernick. It's time to pull back from our fascination with athletics and games.

Comment: The usual media usage ot the word "diversity" is diversity in appearances.  But the more important type of "diversity" is diversity in useful results. 

From a results point of view  - "diversity" in clothing means trying to guess what size actually fits.  Clothes produced in one country that are size "large" are the equivalent of "extra large" produced in second country, and "double XXtra" large when produced in a third country.  The same applies to shoe sizes.  In fact, shoe sizes have another measure of "diversity" - the shoe can be exactly the right length and width, but the shoe can crush your toes because they are too small in top to bottom dimension.  Who could have guessed that there would be a utilitarian usage for clothing?

Comment: I have changed my thinking on the preservation of sf lots in metro Vancouver. I don't think affordability is ever coming back for this housing type.

I live in a sf detached house in Richmond, an area which is seeing 30-40 year old housing stock bulldozed and replaced with large luxury homes.  Lots sell for just under two million, and then add on the cost of the new build.

Many of these huge houses are either never occupied, occupied only part of the year, or occupied by only a handful of people.  No trees, no gardens, paved front yards with only a token amount of landscaping.

I would much rather see more affordable row housing or  townhouses replace it.

Comment: The U.S. Supreme Court has held that the Constitution does not require that Electors be completely free to act as they choose and therefore, political parties may extract pledges from electors to vote for the parties' nominees. Some state laws provide that so-called "faithless Electors" may be subject to fines or may be disqualified for casting an invalid vote and be replaced by a substitute elector. The Supreme Court has not specifically ruled on the question of whether pledges and penalties for failure to vote as pledged may be enforced under the Constitution. No Elector has ever been prosecuted for failing to vote as pledged. 
Today, it is rare for Electors to disregard the popular vote by casting their electoral vote for someone other than their party's candidate. Electors generally hold a leadership position in their party or were chosen to recognize years of loyal service to the party. Throughout our history as a nation, more than 99 percent of Electors have voted as pledged.

Comment: This question could be better worded. Since the right to protest is protected by the 1st Amendment,  the "consequences" would have to come from the private employers. Should the NFL or team owners have sanctions for failure to stand during the playing of the National Anthem? As employers, the NFL and team owners could fire players for failing to follow rules (if they're in place) such as standing for the National Anthem. There could also be loopholes on religious, moral, or contractual grounds. In short, consequences, if any, are in the hands of the organizations. Perhaps a better wording would be: Should we, the public, pressure the NFL and team owners to require all players and staff to stand during the playing of our National Anthem? If yes, then should those who fail to abide be fired? The public could apply pressure in different ways, e.g., boycotting games (live and broadcast), boycotting sponsors of games, public demonstrations, op-eds.

Comment: Well, there's fortunately not too many of the population who'd insist on sitting motionless behind the wheel for 6-7 hours without a break, just for the privilege of driving a more polluting and technically deficient vehicle. Tesla has about a 400 km range currently. Good enough for most, and probably better for your health to stretch your legs every 3-4 hours anyhow.

Maybe what you can't get through your grey-coloured glasses is that climate change requires us to rethink our technologies and investments. If you've got children (or ever were a child, for that matter), maybe it makes some sense to value the health of the planet a little more than your comments would suggest you do.

Increasingly severe weather events like our recent floods will harm ever more citizens, financially, physically, and psychologically; drive up insurance costs; damage infrastructure; and risk catastrophic losses of biodiversity, on which we depend. Maybe worth breaking up your drive a bit to avoid this, no?

Comment: From the article: "for fixing the problem of widening global inequality"
=======

?!?!?  Just what problem of "widening global inequality"???  

Globally speaking inequality has been declining markedly for the past few decades if not longer.  If you look at the highest income earners in the world vs. the lowest income earners in the world the gap has shrunk HUGELY as compared to what it was in, for example, the 1980's.  This decline is mainly due to global trade as the lowest income countries have seen their incomes rise substantially faster than high income countries.

The only place where inequality has grown is within the confines of individual countries.  In low income countries the lowest income earners in that country might now earn 10 times as much as they used to while the highest income earners might earn 20 or 30 times as much.  Globally the poorest are not as poor but within that country income inequality has doubled or tripled.

Comment: In a trip to Japan last year I was struck by the greater obedience of traffic rules by all concerned. Drivers don't think a yellow light means "floor it";  pedestrians don't think the equivalent of a flashing red hand means "run into the intersection to see whether you can get across before the traffic light turns red" and cyclists think red lights apply to them as well. And , as for basic courtesy, there is no comparison. Unsurprisingly, traffic fatality rates are less there than in Canada or the US, despite the much denser urban population.

Comment: Feb 29th 1504 was a good day for Christopher Columbus too. For several months the famous explorer had been marooned on the island of Jamaica. He had been greeted warmly by the natives who helped him and his vast ship and crew survive in the foreign land by providing food and guides etc. However his arrogance and disrespect for the people had caused them to stop this gesture of goodwill. Cause, you know, he was being a dick.

Outraged by this, Columbus consulted his shipboard almanac to ask if there was anything he could use to trick the natives. As it happens, there was a lunar eclipse coming up. On the 29th feb, the day of the eclipse, he gathered the natives and told them that god was angry for their disrespect and would take away the sun. Disappearing inside his ship during the eclipse, he waited as the good people begged for their women and children. He agreed to 'bring the sun back', and essentially enslaved the people until he was rescued.

WHAT A DICK.

Comment: I'm quite familiar with the "training" portion of what HPD does with their MPRs (Metro Police Recruits), and by any standard of any mainland agency, it is an absolute JOKE.  The entire physical screening for applicants, itself, is a joke.  I mean, look at the graduating classes--half of them are already obese, so guess what they'll look like after a decade on the job!

And the so-called "screening" portion of the application process, where they use outdated and archaic psychological inventory tests, regularly lets in guys (and girls) who are obviously unfit for the job; I personally know of several guys who got in, not just after being caught lying on the background and poly, but after disclosing that they are/were on meds for conditions like ADHD.  

HPD is a joke, run by a joke, overseen by a commission of jokes (except Sheehan), and we're lucky more innocent people aren't harmed by having such inferior and unqualified individuals being allowed to wear that uniform.

Comment: We've waited decades to build needed infrastructure and wasted so many opportunities.

Juneau Access's economic benefits are far outweighed by an avalanche-prone route, a border crossing and still needing a ferry. Maintenance costs would be prohibitive for limited value. If it weren't the road to the capitol, nobody would even be talking about it.

The road to Ambler opens up a vast mineral belt that could greatly expand jobs, access to villages and incredible tourism opportunities. It's a road to resources like the Dalton or the Road to Tanana (eventually Nome). These are NEEDED infrastructure like the gasline.

Knik Arm provides access to a much better port site and reduces commuter time from the Valley substantially.

Susitna is one key to NEEDED affordable electricity in the Railbelt.

These are investments. Waiting has only made them more expensive. Had they been built when first proposed we would now have a diversified economy instead of remaining a colony of the US.

Build them!

Comment: MC, in any instance where competition has free reign, private enterprise works well.  But private enterprise does not always work.  Its complicated.  In NYC, garbage collection is absolutely essential with tons piling up blocking the streets within a day or two of failure to collect.  The dire need of service creates great power to extort compensation.  In NYC, unions played a big role in the problem.  The private enterprise companies were hamstrung by unions who knew to power of a strike which would literally shut down the city within days.  With union solidarity, competition between companies was constrained and as a last resort the city assumed the garbage collection function attempting to bring unions and infrastructure under control.  Providers of indispensable services have great power.  They consolidate that power through professional rules.  (Can't be DA without JD and passed bar, can't represent or even be present in court to help a friend without same.)  Real problems exist.

Comment: Real estate makes up 40% of the economy of BC. That is way out of line with historical norms for BC or any other jurisdiction  in North America or around the world ,  creates  a grossly inequitable society with poor jobs for most, and is probably unsustainable in the long run.  The real question of the campaign should be how to create an economy that is not based so much on real estate.  So far as I can tell none of the parties ---and this is especially true for the NDP and the Greens----have anything to offer on this issue at all. As a result, the platforms of all the various parties and the promises they contain all implicitly presuppose  the continuance of the real estate economy, and  their campaigns will be full of noise that distracts from what should be the real issue.

Comment: I hope this father thinks of his fine as tuition in the school of parenting and learns his lessons well. Yes, we should all know better than to leave a child alone in a car, especially a child who cannot free himself. However, I do remember just how hard it was to have a young child. Sleep deprivation causes many of us to not be at our best.

Decades ago, when my child was very young and my spouse and I divided the day in half (we each had twelve hours for work/grad school/sleep/eating and twelve hours when our child was our primary responsibility), I took off from home with my child in a backpack and my dog on a leash. We walked to the nearby grocery store and then on to a hardware store that was two miles further on. As I neared home, I realized that I had left my dog tied up outside the grocery store several hours earlier. That's not quite the same as forgetting about one's child, but it was a warning shot for me to fight the fatigue better.

If you told me there was a proposal to run all the water from roofs, streets, sidewalks, and parking lots through ponds and wetlands I might believe that you are improving water quality, but if you tell me you are going to run relatively pure rainwater through dirt to make it cleaner I wonder if you are testing my gullibility. Comment: The definition of what is "Indian Country" and where the limits of its Constitutionally-ensured sovereignty end is not as cut and dried as "physical borders," particularly when it involves non-tribal members. Thus this bit in the story: 

"The state attorney general's office has no specific policy or guidance on banishments. Generally "banishment orders can present difficult constitutional issues that have to evaluated on a case by case basis," said Cori Mills, an assistant attorney general."

Particularly here in Alaska where, due to the essential lack of treaty-defined reservation lands, the limits of that Sovereignty will often be real but intangible. We are creating and adapting law to fit changing circumstances.

In any event, banishment has a long history as a punishment even in "white" American history, communal beliefs on what punishments are "reasonable" impositions on Rights, and thus Constitutional, and what level of due process may apply, are always open to debate.

Comment: Most small business owners use their corporations to earn and save income for retirement, then once retired split that hard earned money with their spouses. The current proposals would eliminate the ability to split this form of retirement income with a spouse. On the other hand, all of the MPs have glorious pensions which get $6.25 of tax funded matching for every $1 they contribute. So in 2016, when an MP contributed his max of $25,370, his tax funded matching was $158,532.50, for a total accumulated value of $183,932.50. So after serving 6 years the MP has a retirement nest egg of $1,103,595 which he is allowed to split with his spouse upon retirement and is fully indexed. The spouse never worked to earn that income, yet is allowed to split it. If Morneau and the Liberals want to talk about fairness, maybe they should start with a look in the mirror! Most pensions offer a maximum of 1-1 matching. Although I doubt any politician, red, blue, yellow or green would vote to pass this!

Comment: The editorial incorrectly mixes up large scale riverine floodplains and the overland flooding risk the IBC completed to identify 1.8M properties with other types of urban flood risk, beyond river valleys. IBC hired JBA Risk to do 'table land' overland flooding analysis - just a rough estimate of what happens in cities when runoff weaves off roads and between houses during extreme rainfall. That analysis ignored the municipal pipe network underneath so not actually useful to  engineers engaged in flood mitigation at all - and IBC won't share the risk data with municipalities, even if aggregated to forward sorting areas (1st 3 characters of postal codes). The bottom line is no policies should be determined based on the IBC risk "guesstimates". Most urban flood risk is related to sewer pipe back-up that was omitted from the IBC work.

Here is mapping of overland flood risk mapping in Toronto (engineers share):
http://www.cityfloodmap.com/2017/01/city-of-toronto-overland-flow-map-100.html

Comment: It never was easy to buy in Eugene. Missing in the conversation is that many who bought here before the collapse would not even qualify to buy now since some used no income verification loans NIVs, low docs, offerings noticeably absent from current loans at conforming rates. 

You may be surprised that many Realtors cannot qualify to buy a house unless a SALARY is in the mix: 20+% down NIVs were a prime vehicle for self employed persons (which Realtors are). With many deductions, self-employed may be unable to show enough income w/o a big down.

Non-conforming buyers, part-time workers, self-employed historically can't qualify for _conforming front & back end qualifying ratios_ thus _stated income_ loans. Talk about puffing! I have observed in the last 30 years that many buyers had help from family+.

Another angle: many own 5-50 homes. Can we entice some of them to sell to tenants? 
RE: CA influx: 40% of home sales nationwide historically are from people coming from outside an area.

Comment: I'm not opposed to the road, but there are three things that need to be addressed. First, what do you say to the people living in other places prone to awful weather and accessible only by low-quality airstrips with others nearby, such as Russian Mission or Anaktuvik Pass? If you're justifying spending millions of public dollars on a road for King Cove, why not them?

Second, be honest about the use. It's not going to be just for evacuations, everyone knows that. It's going to let cannery traffic access the more cost-effective runway as well. 

Finally, who is going to maintain this road and how. DOT, presumably? Does DOT have sufficient equipment and personnel there or will this require additions? The road is, after all, critical for life and safety, right? It will require regular, year-round [and expensive] maintenance.

I have done business around the world. Most places require giving share ownership to a local citizen and or director in order for a foreign citizen to participate. I have done simple structures and complex structures.

Comment: The existence of accounts of those claiming to have seen miracles is not evidence that they were honest or correct. Plenty of other religions also feature claims of those who said they saw miracles done (e.g. Mohamed moving a mountain) - doesn't mean we should rush out and believe in those.

Or, for that matter, look at some of the crazy "fake news" in modern times - somebody starts a rumour in service to an agenda, and soon you've got a gunman holding up a pizzaria, thinking he's going to reveal to the world Hillary Clinton's pedophile dungeon in the backroom, which he has faith exists because somebody on the internet told him so.

Agnosticism is the sensible position. Maybe there is something greater, maybe not. But if there really is a God, and it indeed operates on the basis of sending everyone who doesn't choose to subscribe to 2000 year old rumours to hell as punishment for our skepticism, that's just power without goodness, and morally unworthy of worship anyway.

Comment: a). increasing CO2 will increase temperatures throughout the Earth. This will make deserts and other types of dry land grow. While deserts increase in size, other eco-zones, whether tropical, forest or grassland will try to migrate towards the poles. However, soil conditions will not necessarily favor their growth even at optimum temperatures.
b). CO2 enhanced plants will need extra water both to maintain their larger growth as well as to compensate for greater moisture evaporation as the heat increases. Where will it come from? Rainwater is not sufficient for current agriculture and the aquifers they rely on are running dry throughout the Earth (California is a good example)
c). High  CO2 level cause a reduction of photosynthesis in certain of plants. There is also evidence from the past of major damage to a wide variety of plants species from a sudden rise in CO2

To sum up, increasing CO2 levels is only be beneficial inside in highly controlled, enclosed spaces like greenhouses.

Comment: I take offense at the authors use of the term 'health-care system'. We do not have a health care system in this country. We have a ongoing, legalized hostage racket. When you are sick, you will do anything to get better, and the system knows it. You will sign onto any agreement to keep yourself alive, even if the system ends up taking your home and your children's educations. 

Services rendered / hours spent / input costs have no anchor in reality for this 'system'. This is true across the board for doctors / hospitals / pharma companies / HMO's / insurance companies who are all engaged in routine, systematic swindling. 

It is plain as day and everyone has experienced it. The $700 strep diagnosis / penicillin shot, the $300 emergency room aspirin, the $6000 broken arm, the impossible to decipher 'explanation of benefits' and attached nickle-and-dime co-pays. All of it is rip off and needs to go.

Comment: In the UK, Canada, and other former British colonies that have adopted the British parliamentary model where there is no impeachment. There are votes of confidence that result in change of government or an election.
All money bills such as budgets are votes of confidence. The opposition can introduce a vote of non confidence and it wins the vote the government falls and it is up to the Governor General to decided with input from the Prime Minister to call an election or ask another person to form a government. 
These non confidence votes that gain the majority support of the House of Commons are usually only successful under minority governments. In Canada, we have about 4-5 parties represented in the House. 
I think under our system, it is a more efficient, effective, and democratic way of changing governments in a matter of a couple of  weeks without an election or 2-3 months with an election.

Comment: Putting aside the exaggerated and unrealistic fears of a "hot war" over this issue, examine the possible actions and retaliations that China could impose, but look at it from the American perspective.

China sells more to the US, than the other way around.

China leverages off of American technology and cultural commerce,(a polite way of saying it steals), not the other way around.

In every field of technology,  commerce and trade, and jobs, the Chinese need the Americans much more than the Americans need the Chinese.

Which leaves the often talked about "balance of payments" threat - the Chinese have invested and loaned trillions in and to the US. What if they stopped loaning, and called those debts?

Well, this quote from the 1930's might be instructive here: " When you owe the bank a thousand dollars, you have a problem. When you owe the bank a million dollars, the bank has a problem."

In the case at hand, who, really, has the worse problem?

Comment: I suggest the "propensity to put everyone into neat little boxes" is the direct result of the way human intelligence works. In every field, including natural science, the intellectual urge is to make distinctions founded in data, and use those distinctions as our understanding of the world.

I further suggest that we see exactly the same propensity to discover "neat little boxes" in emerging gender theories. Just now the field is a bit of a mess, in the sense that everyone and his dog is proposing new distinctions from diverse perspectives. This mess is not bad, but perfectly natural as the human mind struggles to make sense of new data, new observations.

Our Catholic problem is somewhat different, I suggest. There is a powerful tendency to sanctify prior sets of "neat little boxes" rather than be open to new one, based on the false assumption that those prior boxes have been with us from the beginning. Doctrine has always changed, and that crucial fact was not taught in seminaries.

Comment: Ever studied nuclear power plants? Do you know anything about their safety protocols?
What is a "control rod?"
There are procedures in place in EVERY nuclear power plant that covers a grid down contingency. What do you think happens if a tornado wipes out the distribution near any given Nuclear Facility? That aspect is covered.
What is not covered is if the distribution network is destroyed continent wide. The power plants will simply shut down. No problem with them. The citizens, however, will have to deal with having no power, just like Puerto Rico right now . . . only for 1 – 10 years. That is the projected amount of time it would take to get all of those huge transformers back online.
Many folks can deal with a week without power. Maybe two weeks. Could they handle 50 weeks?
From where will their fresh water come? Most places, especially cities, have it pumped. That requires electricity.

Rule of three's applies:
3 weeks without food
3 days without water <--
3 minutes without air

Comment: there is room for debate about the overall impact of mankind's contribution to global warming and neither side will convince the true believers on the other side.  

having said that, there is absolutely no doubt about the toxic effects of carbon dumping into the atmosphere and the oceans.  

acidification of the oceans is quantifiable and cannot be denied.
  
it also cannot be denied that increased carbon levels can be directly related to human activity and that ocean acidification represents a deadly threat to all life on this planet.

instead of arguing the finer points of warming and climate change, the debate should center on the skyrocketing amounts of carbon in the oceans.

that is something everyone can agree on.  

methods for achieving lower carbon levels, whether or not one believes in global warming, should be the crux of the debate.

Comment: Curious that at no point does Saunders mention how many of these apartment-dwellers in Europe have children, or acknowledge the extremely low birth rates in most of those countries. 
France, for example. has resorted to subsidizing larger apartments for parents who want to have a second child. Understandably, most people don't want to have a second child when they live in a tiny two-bedroom apartment. 
Saunders also fails to recognize that one of the reasons most Canadians still regard detached homes as the ideal, despite high levels of immigration, is immigrants themselves regard a detached home as part of the dream. They saved up piles of money, left their familiar homes, to come to a new place because they didn't want to raise their children in hives. 
Personally, I'd rather live in the most squalid house in the worst neighbourhood in Calgary than in the nicest condo unit in the city. Without grass and trees and privacy, I'd go crazy.

Comment: PLEASE READ FROM FIRST COMMENT POSTED.

That the subject matter of the initiative petition only addresses ‘matter of county concern’ is not one of the constitutional requirements for the initiative process. Just as, on the state level, a statute’s constitutionality is evaluated only after it has been adopted.” Bowers v. Betschart and Bloomgarden et al., Lane County Circuit Court Case No. 15CV28768.

In short, that an initiative pertains to “matters of county concern” is not one of the procedural requirements that can be reviewed pre-election. Jay Bozievich acknowledges that “currently, the question of whether a measure deals with county concerns is not reviewed until after election.” Indeed, this is true because “matters of county concern” can only be reviewed post-election because it would be unconstitutional to review that question pre-election.

If Judge Carlson’s ruling is not clear enough for the County Commission, Oregon statute, ORS 203.035, which addresses:

Comment: My family has deep roots in our near north, which span the time when the Hudson's Bay Company first arrived here, at Moose Factory where their first major trading post was created by Joseph Isbister. Our Orkneuy Scottish family sent 14 young men over 150 years from just the one farm in Firth and Stennes on Orkney, as well as so many cousins. The rivermouth communities in the north were all created considering the fur trade. The Moose River, the Albany River, the Attawapiskat River, the Ekwan River, the Winisk River, the Severn River....all flowing into the salt water from Northern Ontario, established trade outpost villages at their mouths. Every spring native trappers floated downstream in the high water, with canoes laden with rich soft furs destined for England and Europe. If Kathlene Wynne wanted to really do something for the native north, she could start by wearing a fur coat, and presenting herself as a pro fur-trade premier. She would be Fur Trader #1 in Canada...a comeback.

Comment: Along the same lines, while I was chair and trustee for the Halton Catholic District school board each school was to select one staff person to recognize each year.  Within a couple of years each school selected the caretaker because it had been decided by teachers (as instructed by their unions) to not recognize any one teacher over any other.  This type of thinking is yet one more example of our rush towards mediocrity.  

Likewise, when the school board was asked to recognize one of its high school students who had won international awards for developing a program to help autistic children communicate, it was commented by several trustees that it would not be appropriate to recognize this one student because "we have so many good students".  My response:  Yes, that's true, so let's start with this one !

We need to think, would that kind of thinking have put a man on the moon?  Or perhaps more importantly, will that kind of thinking find a cure for cancer or address world hunger?

Comment: Richard, you seem to have the text-book neo-conservative stance on tax structure.  However, taxes need a linkage between the resource provided and the beneficiary of that resource.  Wealthy individuals and corporations benefit from all the publicly-funded resources of our state and country vastly more than working class and poor individuals, in terms of the economic benefit derived.   Who do you think benefits more from our infrastructure, rule of law, military security and educational system?  A working-class stiff or Warren Buffet?  Of course Buffet benefits more on an almost incalculable scale.  A guy using a street to get to his job doesn't get the same benefit as a billionaire who ships his good over that same road at a profit.  You can't tax people who have no excess discretionary income - there's nothing to tax.  And generation of excess discretionary income is the only meaningful indicator as to who should pay taxes.

Comment: Per Mr. Russell's appeal to the Anchorage Assembly to repeal property tax exemptions for seniors and religious entities.  Reasonable minds can disagree as to the appropriateness of these exemptions but, if you are among those who feel they should be repealed don't bother contacting the Assembly as the exemptions are mandated by state law - the Assembly can't do a darn thing about it.  

Instead, you need to contact your state legislators and ask they repeal or amend the applicable statutes. If they do so then that would be the appropriate time to contact Assembly members.

Best of luck!

Patrick Flynn
Happily retired Anchorage Assembly member

Comment: I think Bernardin's metaphor (and it is intentionally a metaphor) of the seamless garment is an example of what Norman Perrin called a "tensive symbol," which, unlike steno symbols, describe a reality (in Perrin's case, the parables attributed to Jesus) without actually defining it. So the kingdom of God is "like" a mustard seed, and so on.
I don't think we can reasonably argue that the metaphor of a seamless garment can be required of every believer in practice, since one's practical support for or opposition to many situations is outside one's control. (I will never declare war, sentence someone to death, etc.) The decision to abort a fetus or not, on the other hand, is one most women can and do make during their lifetimes. In this sense, I agree that this intensely personal decision is qualitatively different from most other decisions. And this in spite of my pro-choice position, which goes well beyond Roe v. Wade.

If the figure is truly (and currently) 8% of claims being false, that is still a significant minority of cases...therefore it is not a common occurrence.  Any false claim is too many and they shouldn't happen, but it is inaccurate to suggest that false claims are common.

A side note: that purported 8% value will likely drop (as a percentage) if the process changes and more people choose to come forward to report the crimes because of increased confidence in the system.  Right now many will not come forward because of the perception that they will not be treated properly.

One country in particular stands out above the others, but, if one does sub-totaling by country of coal-generation of power, it stands out well above what is intuitive. Until "the world", whatever that means, faces the fact that China, almost to exclusivity, is fouling our planet at rates completely unimaginable, then "the world" will play games pretending "concern" by putting their names on a list with China in Paris.

Comment: Their own land? Since the tribes agreed to the reservation boundaries in 1868, this area has not been "their land". In that Treaty, the northern boundary was the 46th parallel at the Missouri river. In an executive order in 1873, the northern boundary was extended to the Cannon Ball River, which is south of the pipeline route. The reservation was centered in the Fort Yates Agency in 1873, located in South Dakota. So, in fact, it is not their land and has not been since the Treaty of 1868, in which the Sioux tribes accepted the reservation boundaries. The part the Sioux Nations do not accept is the 1877 annexation of the Black Hills. I do not blame them for that because it was done without the required approval of the Sioux tribes as stipulated in Section 2 of the Treaty of 1868.

Comment: I will admit that I was staunchly opposed to these sites initially. But I've come to see the benefits of them. To those who are like I was, I put forth that one should ignore the love-and-hugs-for-all that these articles put forth. There are many benefits:

1 - Rehab options can be presented to those most likely to have positive effects, with the goal of getting them off of drugs

2 - Medical services are centralized. One crew can staff one site, with all material on hand, rather than EMTs running all over town whenever someone overdoses

3 - Clean-up cost reduction. Both in terms of used syringes, and in overdose cases that couldn't be saved. Everything gets bagged on-site, and sent for efficient disposal

4 - A steady stream of voluntary research subjects for affects of addiction, and long-term narcotics use

5 - The current shadow-population of addicts become a known quantity

The list goes on.

Comment: Your arguments against single payer are not convincing, Charles.  You say that controlling costs is the only long-term solution, and I certainly can't argue with that.  There needs to rational controls on specialist physician and hospital billing (and that includes non-profits, which appear to be equally capable of price gouging as for profit providers), control of pharmaceutical and medical equipment costs and some control of the cost of litigation in health care.  Conservatives, though, need to come to grips with the fact that we do not have a free market based health care system in the U.S. now, haven't for many decades, and will almost certainly never have it again.  Rather than arguing that repealing ACA will allow the free market to work (which is ridiculous, because the loss of free market controls in health care predated ACA by many decades) They need to think about what mechanisms CAN enforce cost controls. I believe that can only be achieved through a single payer system.

Comment: Mental disability is not treated any differently they only classify the animal differently.  It is called emotional support animal or ESA.  And even international airlines recognize and follow the federal rules regarding these animals for American travelers.  As long as you're flying
From America to your destination and back to America.  

The fact that our local airlines dropped the damn ball is absurd.  As long as you have a letter from a doctor (doesn't matter If your disability is mental or physical) then you have a legal right to your service or ESA animal.  This not only includes flying, transport but living arrangements as well.  Places that don't accept pets must accept a service animal because it is legally not considered a pet.  Don't like the laws? Lobby against them.  But the law is the law.

Comment: "The boycott was fueled when a community newspaper no longer in business reported that Jimmy fired all of the former Front Street Market employees in a move to switch to a nonunion workforce and was hiring new employees at just $10 per hour.

Jimmy explained to the Reporter that he never fired anyone, as it was impossible to fire people who weren’t already his employees. He stated that he offered all of the former Front Street Market employees $15 per hour to come work for him, but that 10 had refused."

Sorry, but that's bogus. You buy an existing business, you don't start from scratch; you're buying the "brand", the name, the goodwill of existing customers, etc, as well as the stock, the equipment, etc.

And yes, you're also taking on the employees. They were employees of the business; while the owner of the business changed, the business itself (and the employees) didn't. Coming in and breaking the union and offering less money or else they're out of a job is definitely firing them.

Comment: In Ontario, there are 1.25 people per 100,000 that die every year due to drowning (as per the Ontario Life Saving report found here: http://www.lifesaving.ca/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/Ontario-Drowning-Report-2016.pdf) which means that in a city the size of Cambridge, you have between 1 and 2 people that drown every year. If you look at the statistics, since 1990, the numbers are declining slowly (from 685 in 1993 to the lowest year, 433 in 2004 to the current stats for last year of 466), a decline of 32% in 20 years.

Here's the point and it is called the law of diminishing returns. No matter what you do, you will never get that number to zero, ever. And the cost to get it to zero is very high, and for a reduced segment of the population like those with autism, at 2.83% for boys and 0.53% for girls (https://www.autismspeaks.org/what-autism/prevalence), it will be practically infinite. Any difficulty where a person has free will has the same problem. Money is not the answer.

Comment: This article itself is misleading. Olsovsky may indeed call himself a doctor - that is what the D in OD stands for. Further, optometrists DO treat the eye - for example, contact lenses come in contact with the eyeball, causing infection and requiring treatment frequently. They also diagnose and treat certain diseases of the eye, while this article's lead implies that they don't. It is true that optometrists have a much narrower scope of practice than ophthalmologists and it's unlawful to practice outside of that scope. Olsovsky is not necessarily guilty of that just because he put M.D. after his name, which is a designation it sounds as if he earned (albeit in another country). I'm no lawyer but that sounds more like false advertising (since he's not licensed as an M.D. in Oregon).

Comment: Mahalo Chad and CB for drawing attention to a topic which is all too often overlooked. When individuals or groups make sincere efforts to protect the natural world, they should be thanked, recognized and supported. But if those efforts are undertaken because they are mandated by law, politically expedient or fit into a greater plan that prioritizes the "full spectrum dominance" of nature to advance national interests at the expense of others' human rights, security and a healthy environment, then they should be closely scrutinized. It's hard to swallow the good "green" narrative of the US military when its mission requires the forced destruction of biologically rich coastal and marine environments, the destruction of coral reefs, and the bulldozing of forests to build helipads in order to test and train for war. One only has to look at what the US military is doing at #Henoko and #Takae in Okinawa right now to see a callous disregard for the environment it says it cares about so much.

Comment: Re the Holy Spirit, John 14.16f. has these words of Jesus (according to the NRSV, a translation which you may or may not consider inspired): "And I will ask the Father, and he will give you another Advocate, to be with you forever. This is the Spirit of truth, whom the world cannot receive, because it neither sees him nor knows him. You know him, because he abides with you, and he will be with you." In Greek, "Spirit" is the neuter-gender "pneûma"; and the relative and personal pronouns translated here as "whom" and "him" are ALL in the neuter gender. (The two "he"s render no expressed pronoun.) In the Vulgate, "pneûma" is rendered by "spiritus," which is masculine-gender, so the pronouns should be understood to be masculine also.

The thing is, we English-speakers don't like to use "it" to refer to an active intelligent agent with whom we are supposed to feel sympathy. So though "it abides with you" is strictly accurate, we moderns tend not to be ready to accept it here.

Comment: It's an interesting dilemna.  I abhor censorship, but there is a pattern I've witnessed repeatedly. 

A *lie* is posted by a Leftist with an axe to grind. The lie is refuted, the facts demolish all credibility of the lie and the liar. The following day, the lie is *REPOSTED* in twelve different threads, and the liar complains to the board's moderators that the refutation of the lies is harassment.

Truth be told, I DO NOT KNOW what the appropriate cure for the above problem is.  What I do know (from personal experience) is that after several rounds of the above, the reputation of the poster who has the truth to fall back upon (me),  tends to result in one of two typical outcomes: 1) When the mods are honest and the forum is impartial, the liars tend to get banned, until they assume new monikers.  2) The mods ignore the lies, (maybe) ask the abusers to stop the duplicate posts, or freeze the threads with the lies in place and the rebuttals frozen out.

Comment: I noted to Colkoch previously that Jesus is not the model for distribution or reception of Holy Communion; that belongs to the Rite.  
The Melkites, a Byzantine Rite group found primarily in Syria, use leavened bread and wine to be consecrated.  A relatively large piece of Consecrated Bread is placed into the Chalice and the resulting mixture is placed on the communicant's tongue using a small spoon.  The Maronite Rite and some other Eastern Rites use intinction as, in some relatively few cases, does the Latin Rite.  The image of the Last Supper, then, is not the mode of distribution or reception - else all would also recline around tables and speak Aramaic - but of Jesus being fully present in the Sacred Species and given to us to consume.

Comment: While polling numbers show Governor Ige is vulnerable in the abstract, there is a saying in politics, "You can't beat somebody with nobody.” So which politicians might be able to mount a serious challenge against him? The LG is running for Maui mayor. None of the four county mayors can do it. Not Caldwell, hurt by the disasters of Rail. Not Bernard Cravalho of Kauai, though he is making sounds. Not the Speaker of the House, not the Senate President. In fact, no state legislator is making sounds, though senators Green, Espero and Tokuda are looking at LG.

If she were to run, Congresswoman Hanabusa is rumored to have the backing of the Ariyoshi and Team Inouye groups, and some of the unions. Among voters, some opposition to Ige comes from an uninformed bias against AJA Democrats, as well as an "anti-incumbent" mood. In a race where Hanabusa would be seen as "the Machine candidate," it is not clear voters would support her against  the more independent Ige. It would be a tough race.

Comment: I submit that Mr. Oman is part of the problem.  He is a long-time Alaska resident who doesn't even know who is Representative and Senator are, but he knows his political party affiliation. Comment: I really don't understand climate change skeptics. The science is overwhelming .. the consensus among nations is overwhelming .. even many energy companies now publicly profess their commitments to change .. 
Add to that the sheer implausibility of a tacit global agreement between thousands of scientists working across dozens of disciplines to fudge climate data and/or its interpretation, and I just can't wrap my head around why anyone would conclude that it's all fakery.
Sure, a lot of early predictions didn't come to pass and we're still not sure what the exact effects will be and when they'll happen .. but that's no reason to declaim against the whole idea of anthropogenic climate change since the basic facts remain: 
1. Atmospheric CO2 directly impacts global climate systems, and
2. Human activity is causing CO2 levels to rise.
We won't kill the planet or ourselves, but the global economic and social instability will hobble us for generations.

Comment: I think SB91 had an amendment offered that would have expanded red stripe driver's license usage for people on probation or parole. I don't know if it made it into the bill.

The problem with having the stores do it is that without state sanction or mandate they would then be liable for, and almost certainly hit with, claims of "discrimination." At this point they can bar individuals from stores who have committed crimes there, that's a remaining part of the right to refuse service, but they can't just pick and choose who to serve.

In any event, people who are (legally) barred from stores or who have red-stripe licenses now still get booze simply by having someone else go in and buy for them. There will always be someone willing to do that.

As for raising costs on the cheap stuff, I don't know the actual numbers but there are a lot of non-trouble-making and otherwise functional and contributing citizens out there who shouldn't be penalized for the acts of a few.

Comment: "Was Trump's request to Comey an obstruction of justice?"

Remove all the political and legal blather, and the obvious answer is no.

You actually have to do something to impede an investigation to commit the criminal offence of OOJ. For example, if you ask a cop not to write you a ticket for speeding, you haven't obstructed justice. The cop's either going to write you a ticket or he isn't based on his assessment of what happened. Your request is inappropriate, but nothing more.

In Trump's case he too made an inappropriate comment to a law enforcement official- "I hope you can let it go." Inappropriate, yes. Criminal, no.

Comment: Perhaps you don't understand grant money. It is not paid back, and usually has a matching amount put up by the organization applying for the grant. Grants are offered all over for many different purposes from libraries to school police to teen centers to hospitals, etc. I even got a snowmachine through a grant for emergency search and rescues for a city. Some of the grant money might come from state, local, and even private sources (Rasmussen puts grants out annually along with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation). You need to do your homework and understand the concept and where they come from.

Comment: IMO There has only been 4 ways out of this budget mess:
1.Using PF earnings
2.Slashing oil tax credits
3.Raising new tax revenues
4.Slashing the state budget

Since we don't seem to be able to get a combined approach out of the legislature we may be doomed to piecemeal attempts- of which the first is a PFD reduction. With all due respect to everyone who feels the PFD should be a personal entitlement - I can't help but think Senator W, - aided in the lawsuit by Halford and Tillion - are playing right into the hands of those whose first priority is slashing state spending. 

Seems to me that by forcing everyone to sacrifice part of their PFD - that might be enough to get our legislature off the dime to raise the other revenues and avoid slashing the state budget beyond repair. 

This PFD cut may not feel fair nor right nor legal to many people. But the fiscal hole we are facing is far far greater than what the governor has withheld from your PFD. And we really need to take a first step.

Comment: That article is written by a developer. Can't trust it at all. Microhousing maximizes developer profits at the expense of existing people who live in the neighborhood. Parking that you currently pay the city for becomes nonexistent. I'm pro-microhousing so long as people who live there don't qualify for RPZ permits. Today that isn't the case. Plus as I said before, Eastlake still has so much Microhousing under construction and planned that what you are reading just isn't true. It's very, very much alive in Seattle, and it sucks for anyone with dreams of a family who wants to stay for the long-term. Balance is needed, but with Microhousing developers have no incentive to build anything else. Amazon intern season will fill them all up for the summer at insane prices no matter what. Microhousing in Eastlake is often $1200/month, not cheap and a terrible cost per square foot. No one wins but developers. To top it off, zoning by the lake now allows higher buildings, ruining it for everyone.

Comment: " ... fresh off their meeting with the UN committee in Geneva earlier this week" ...
I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: This is an example of what I'm talking about, Jerry, in terms of trying to redefine ordinary phrases and common-sense ideas. Here you try to argue that Obama's trip to meet with Abe is not historic, because Obama comes to Hawaii regularly. Last I checked, when two stakeholders travel to the same place to do the same thing, and it's a historic thing, they both get credit for making the historic thing happen. Since their meeting is not coincidental, and Abe wouldn't be doing this without Obama's participation, it is a watershed moment in Pearl Harbor history; viola, it's a historic trip for both of them. ... Not sure why we spend time on trivial points like this, when the theme of the column is that journalists are getting left out of important cultural, historical, societal conversations, which means, you, as an extension, also are being left out. Instead of first-hand reporting, and getting closer to truth, we just get a bunch of armchair sophistry practice.

Comment: Another issue that has been ignored is the unfair or inequitable treatment of homeowners and other asset owners regarding income on capital gains. In a logical world all income would be taxed the same. This would include salaries, capital gains on home sales, professional income, and capital gains on stock or other asset sales. This would go a long way to take some of the heat out of the real estate and stock markets, as both are inflated assets (aka bubbles). But if one wishes to maintain the capital gains exemptions on homes, it could be made more equal if it was a once in a lifetime thing and it was only for the average value of a home in Canada at the time of the claim, so the playing field was more equitable or equal. Increasing the holding period from one year to a five year minimum, with the holder being required to have paid personal income tax in Canada for that period might also help. These are all understandable and addressable issues.

Ontario, New Brunswick and Manitoba particularly stand out as problem area, their budgets really SHOULD have been balanced 3 years ago.

Comment: Perfect information, from an economics perspective, rarely occurs.  However, that does not mean that the employment market is immune to the forces of supply and demand.  As an HR professional you are doubtless aware of employee churn as an example -- which increases when compensation/working conditions become unfavourable relative to competition.

In the lower end of the job market, high demand for labour increases the wages.

Alberta is an excellent example of both phenomena -- back in the last oil boom minimum wage was not sufficient to attract service workers etc.  Now with depressed oil prices the converse is true.

Comment: "That ratio (of 11) means that the typical Vancouver resident needs 11 times his or her income to purchase the typical home."

What a laughably misleading statement that is.

Look, the average house price in Vancouver is about 1.5 million dollars (reference 1 below).

The average yearly income in Vancouver is about 56,000 dollars (reference 2 below).

Hello, that is a ratio of 27.

Yes, 27!

And come on, most people think of houses when they think of homes.

But even the average price of just a condominium in Vancouver is about 620,000 dollars (reference 3). That means that a mere condominium is selling for about 11 times the average annual local salary.

Summary: The news report hopelessly underestimates just how bad the pricing ratios are in Vancouver.

References:

1. zolo.ca/vancouver-real-estate/trends
2. payscale.com/research/CA/Location=Vancouver-British-Columbia/Salary
3. http://dailyhive.com/vancouver/vancouver-real-estate-average-home-prices-q3-2017

Comment: Once again, in the light of day in Anchorage, someone was either distracted or just plain too rushed to watch for wildlife entering the roadway. The wolf had a fish and game radio collar on. Those collars are not tiny pet collars. There are no other white wolves here. 
So sad this happened. 
I never thought cohabitating with wildlife meant total disregard for their existence. Not saying this was the case here but as the moose kill numbers continue to rise, you need to ask yourself, am I paying attention to my surroundings? Wildlife do not follow human road rules and never will. Part of living in Alaska is knowing that and being vigilant.
Thank goodness it wasn't a child but it very well could have been in a speed obsessed city. I would almost bet that the years spent waiting at lights around town could be playing a role in some of these incidents. This is the only state I've lived in where you can sit at a light waiting 5 minutes for no one before finally getting the green light to go.

Comment: It's raining outside.....must be those damn public employees causing it... The PERS unfunded mandate is a creation of public employERS taking the "short, easy way out" and not funding the "PERS-pick-up" as it was due.  Instead they delayed payment of those funds until retirement.  Consequently, that "unfunded mandate" grew each year for each employee.  Had those public employers paid the PERS pick-up each month along with the "employer contribution", there would be virtually NO unfunded mandate.  Folks shouldn't blame the public employees.  It was the legislature, school boards, city and county governments, et al who chose to NOT pay the contribution as it was "credited" to employee retirement accounts.... This, as we're seeing today, was a MASSIVE mistake. Gary Crum

Comment: "Energy companies are making a 'strategic mistake' and could waste billions of dollars of investment by thinking they are immune to climate policy", says International Energy Agency (IEA) chief economist Fatih Birol. The world's fossil fuel companies risk wasting billions of dollars by not taking global action to fight climate change seriously. "If they think that their business are immune to the impacts of climate policy, they are making a strategic mistake." (The Guardian, July 09, 2015)
The Wold Bank and Bank of England  have already warned of the serious risk climate action poses to trillions of dollars of fossil fuel investments.
A "Carbon Tracker" report (analysis backed by the Bank of England and the World Bank), reveals keeping to emissions targets (2ºC) would render obsolete more than $1 trillion of oil investments and $280 billion worth of global liquefied natural gas projects. 
Mr. Trudeau should read those reports before making his policy decisions on energy and pipelines.

Comment: No, Rebecca.

1.  The product added does not contain fluorosilic acid.  It is fluorosilic acid, a compound which contains fluoride ions, identical to those which already exist in water.  Once FSA releases its fluoride ions, it no longer exists in that water.  It does not reach the tap.  It is not ingested.  It is of no concern, whatsoever.

2.  Due to the ubiquity of arsenic throughout nature, it is difficult to find anything that does not contain it.  Arsenic exists in water naturally.  The barely detectable amounts of “arsenic, lead, and other chemicals” in water fluoridated with FSA are so minuscule, so far below EPA mandated maximum allowable levels of safety that it is not even a certainty that those detected are not those that already exist in the water naturally.

3. There is no “Harvard study” that concludes fluoride to be a neurotoxin.

4.  The only “teeth fluorosis” associated with fluoridated water is barely detectable mild to very mild.

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: "No, the climate doesn't change every 6 months."
Sure it does. For example, a region or city may tend to be warm and humid during summer. But it may tend to be cold and snowy during winter. It's a natural occurrence called "seasonal climate change" and happens like clockwork every 6 months or so.
The difference now is that the climate change we are currently experiencing is causing more severe seasonal climates ... warmer and more humid than usual in the summer and colder and snowier than usual in the winter. It may or may not be fully or partially human induced ... but what difference does it make? Doing nothing is not an option. Either we do something about it, or we suffer the consequences. Some suggestions I've heard is to clean up the atmosphere, build seawalls, raise structures within low lying areas, adopt building codes to better withstand extreme storms, etc. I'm open to other suggestions. Any ideas, Taboot?

Best,

RTD

Comment: The_Bad_one, That's not my definition, that's what's used in the Militia Act of 1903, which describes two groups.  The organized militia consists of State militia forces, notably, the National Guard and Naval Militia.  The unorganized militia consists of every able-bodied man of at least 17 and under 45 years of age who is not a member of the National Guard or Naval Militia.  The Second Amendment grants gun ownership rights to members of a "well regulated militia" -- the organized militia, not the unorganized militia.

Comment: For the umpteenth IWD in a row, the G&M ran a couple of articles that covered the "wage gap". Comment: I would like to see more respect for facts and logic in American politics. On the other hand some of what the economists tell us is questionable. The unemployment rate, for example, does not include people who have given up looking for work, doesn't tell us what groups are doing well and which aren't, and is a temporary snapshot. The economy moves in short cycles but long-term trends, such as the reduction of people in the workforce, are more important. Likewise it's hard to accept low inflation figures when you checkout at the supermarket.

It's hard for working-class people to trust happy talk from the "experts" when we're struggling to get by. The upper middle-class professional experts are doing well, but we are not. This is what has fueled both the Trump and Sanders campaigns, but well-paid columnists and politicians don't seem to get it. For all their expertise and knowledge, we have to wonder if they're on our side.

Check out "Listen Liberal" by Thomas Frank.

Comment: In 1991, Crimea voted 94.3% in favour to leave Ukraine and become an autonomous republic of the USSR. Of course, the USSR disbanded later in 1991, and Crimea became an autonomous region in Ukraine.
In 1994, Crimea's independence and pro-Russia movement was growing, and Crimea formed a separatist government.
the UN polled Crimea quarterly from 2009 - 2011, and each time found that a majority of Crimean residents wanted to rejoin Russia.
In 2014, around the time of the Maiden coup in Kiev, and pre-referendum in Crimea, various international pollsters found that nearly 80% of polled Crimean residents wanted to rejoin Russia.
Post Crimean referendum, many international pollsters investigated the satisfaction of Crimeans with the referendum outcome, and typically found that over 85% of Crimeans were fully satisfied with the referendum outcome, while further Crimeans were mostly or generally satisfied with the referendum outcome.
The polling of Crimea is consistent and clear.

Comment: High income earners pay the lions share of all taxes so it is inevitable that anything that reduces taxes will disproportionately benefit higher income earners.

Put another way, if someone is only paying $20/year in total income taxes, the most you can possibly cut their taxes by is $20, or a 100% decrease.  If someone else is paying $10,000/year in taxes and you cut their taxes by $200 they benefited 10 times as much as the first person even though they only saw a 2% decrease in their taxes.

The notion that we can't have any programs that help reduce the tax burden just because those programs might benefit high income earners more is completely misguided and ignorant.

Comment: Good points, each one. However I do have a counter point:

Why should I pay for other people’s healthcare when I can barely afford my own?
1.	Why should I pay for your police protection? Pay for that on your own.
2.	Why should I pay for the construction and maintenance of the roads, sewers, and other 
        infrastructure you use?
3.	Why should I pay for fire protection for you?
4.	Why should I pay for people who inspect your food and drugs? Do it yourself.
5.	Why should I pay for a judge or courtroom if you want to sue somebody?
6.	Seems to me you are just as much a taker as the person wanting healthcare.

To continue; the GOP mantra is that health care is simply a product. They have no objection to people paying for that product; but they have HUGE objections to paying for somebody ELSE to have that product. Therefore, ANY reduction of public taxes to provide for healthcare is a good result, better than the status quo. The US won't need healthcare when all the uninsured just die.

Comment: Getting rid of a way to truncate long reply threads seems like it might cause other problems. For example, if folks are sorting the comments by what's most popular (which is a handy feature) and there isn't a way to truncate the replies, everyone who replies to the top-most comment has their post appear above everyone else who simply posts to the main thread. Something like this: 

1. I'm the most popular comment! 
     a. response
     b. response
     c. response
     d. response
     e. response
     f. response
     g. response
     h. response
     i. response
     J. response
2. I'm the second most popular comment.  
     a. response
     b. response
     c. response

Imagining a scenario where the most popular comment has 200 responses on it, this could be a real pain. 

Perhaps seeing the four most popular responses to each comment could be done? I'm not sure.
